sections.title: What is a Gameplay Loop?
sections.text: A gameplay loop is the core mechanic that players go through repeatedly. In RPGs, these loops are especially important as they form the foundation for hundreds of hours of gameplay.

sections.title: The Three Levels
sections.text: Successful RPGs have multiple interlocking loops:

items.text: Micro-Loop (Seconds to Minutes): The basic combat mechanics: Attack, dodge, use abilities. This loop must feel good since it's repeated most frequently.
Meso-Loop (10-30 Minutes): Complete a dungeon, finish a quest, defeat a boss. Here you get bigger rewards like new items or abilities.
Macro-Loop (Hours to Days): Character progression, story progress, unlock new areas. These loops give the game structure and long-term goals.

sections.title: Design Principles
sections.text:
When designing gameplay loops, consider:

  • Constant Rewards: Players should regularly feel progress
  • Variability: The loop should evolve and not become monotonous
  • Clear Feedback: Players must understand what they've achieved
  • Scaling: The loop should become harder with player level

sections.title: Example: Diablo Series
sections.text:
Diablo is a prime example of perfect gameplay loops:

Micro: Kill monsters ‚Üí Collect loot ‚Üí Get stronger
Meso: Complete dungeon ‚Üí Defeat boss ‚Üí Legendary item
Macro: Increase difficulty ‚Üí Optimize build ‚Üí Endgame content

items.text: Too Long Wait Times: When rewards come too rarely, players lose motivation.
No Escalation: The loop should evolve - introduce new mechanics, enemies and challenges.
Missing Variation: Even the best loop becomes boring if it's too repetitive. Build in variety.
